column5: Students
column8: Title
column9: Video
column10: Abstract
column11: Slides

column5: Thai Thuy Anh Le
column6: Celia A. Schiffer, Nese Kurt Yilmaz, Patricia Z. Musacchio, George A. Kaminski
column8: Comparison of Sequences and Structures Between NS3-NS2B of Various Flaviviruses
column10: Flaviviridae is a family of single-stranded RNA viruses, which include Hepacivirus, Pestivirus, Pegivirus, and Flavivirus. Many members of the Flavivirus genus are known to cause fatal encephalitis and hemorrhagic illness in humans, such as Dengue virus (DENV), and Murray Valley virus (MVEV). By comparing sequences and structures between their Nonstructural protein 3 (a multi-purpose protein that is crucial for Flavivirus' RNA replication), using sequence alignment and structural alignment algorithm, this project's goal is to find conserved regions and sequences among those proteins. This information can help researchers examine the relatedness between the members of Flaviviruses, and develop effective treatment.

column5: Emily Stead, Kathryn Nippert, Luigi Apollon
column6: Jagan Srinivasan, Carissa Olsen, Angela C. Incollingo Rodriguez
column8: Selegiline: The Effects of Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors on the Behavior and Physiology of Caenorhabditis Elegans
column10: This study observed the effects of Selegiline on behavioral and metabolic pathways of C. elegans by investigating egg laying behavior, locomotion, and lipid composition. Selegiline positively impacts egg-laying but negatively impacts locomotion. Lipid composition data revealed an increase in saturated FA content and decreased polyunsaturated FA content, suggesting FAT-2 or FAT-7 enzyme dysregulation. A survey of WPI students identified positive correlations between perceived stress and depressive symptoms with the average student's CES-D score measuring 24.2, which is considered depressed. These results highlight the increased prevalence and importance of understanding the physiology and biological mechanisms implicated in depression.

column5: Lily Cordner, Sammy Hankaoui, Delainey O'Connor, Emily Pollock, Blake Wofford
column8: A Preliminary Analysis of Healthcare Disparities Curriculum at WPI
column10: Undergraduate bioengineering and biomedical sciences curriculum is currently lacking the inclusion of healthcare disparities education. It is imperative to educate future healthcare professionals as early in their career as possible in order to mitigate these disparities in their later work. The purpose of this study was to look at the degree and manner in which students have intersected with healthcare disparities. Another focal point of the study was to examine the effectiveness of an educational module administered to students taking courses in biomedical sciences, bioengineering, and adjacent disciplines.

column5: Christopher Tocci
column8: Social Determinants of COVID-19 Development & Microbial Species Associated with COVID-19 Comorbidities in Worcester, MA
column10: Coronavirus Disease 2019, caused by the spread of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-Coronavirus-2 has been particularly detrimental to marginalized populations within Worcester, Massachusetts. Utilizing data from the Worcester Department of Public Health and the U.S. Census Bureau, this project first focused on identifying key social determinants associated with coronavirus. Further investigations were carried out with researchers at UMASS Medical School to ascertain whether specific members of the oral microbiota are correlated with worsening comorbidities following recovery from COVID-19.

column5: Isabel Bowman, Kendall Pacheco, Javier Sibel, Ziyan Xie
column8: Impact Mouthguard Sensor to Detect Real Time Rotational and Linear Acceleration
column10: Traumatic brain injuries (TBIs) occur when a force acts upon your head resulting in two forms of acceleration through the skull. These blows are characterized by linear and rotational acceleration. There is currently no prevention for TBIs, but there are treatments to aid the symptoms that go along with the injury. Studies show that the more TBIs that one person obtains, the more severe the damage could be, ultimately leading to CTE which could be fatal. The goal of this project is to produce a device that will measure head impact through a mouthguard sensor that will detect rotational and linear acceleration in real-time. This product can be utilized for any contact or collision sports for youth up to professional athlete.

column5: Sarah Boermeester
column8: Characterizing Composite Microthreads
column10: Discrete fibrin microthreads are a type of matrix scaffold that offer the potential to address volumetric muscle loss when used as a scaffold for muscle tissue. One way to optimize these mircrothreads would be to incorporate the delivery of drugs, antibiotics, or growth factors from the threads, as it would provide benefits to the local implantation site. Silk fibroin is a material that has been widely used in drug delivery and offers tunable properties and the ability to deliver a variety of molecules and proteins. The goal of this project was to investigate and characterize the use of silk microparticles as a composite material when incorporated into fibrin microthreads.

column5: Abigail Leonardi, Gillian Miller
column6: Izabela Stroe, Maqsood Mughal, Amhet Can Sabuncu, Cagdas Onal
column8: An Endoscopy Probe for Early Colorectal Cancer Detection
column10: Colonoscopies are routine procedures for many adults. For individuals with IBD these procedures are annual. Polyps or precancerous tissue is missed the most in this population as their inflamed bowels make it difficult to detect these regions. Cancerous tissue development is associated with increased conductivity as tight junction activity increases the flow of ions. We developed a coaxial probe to scan electrical properties of tissues, like conductance. The proposed design would be incorporated with current colonoscopes and fed through the working channel of these devices. Future studies will be required to test the device's ability to differentiate cancerous tissue.

column5: Jenna Currie, Thomas Lipkin, Dana Landry, Sarah Vasquez
column6: Pradeep Radhakrishnan, Dirk Albrecht, Kaveh Pahlavan
column8: Investigating the Use of Magnetic Actuation to Develop a Functional Tongue Prosthetic to Mimic Human Deglutition
column10: The goal of this project is to utilize magnetic actuation to create a functional tongue prosthetic for oral cancer patients. Glossectomy is a surgical procedure in which the tongue is removed mainly due to cancer and has affects on the eating and speaking of patients. Currently, tongue prosthetics are static and lack any functionality. Our project aimed to miniaturize the electrical components to fit within the oral cavity and move the prosthetic to aid with feeding. Magnetic actuation was explored and utilized as the method of movement.

column5: Beck Arruda
column8: Metalinguistic Awareness & Language Learning
column10: Learning a second language typically makes learning a third easier. The hypothesized reason for this improved language learning ability is metalinguistic awareness: the ability to consciously and explicitly think about linguistic form, such as the grammar of a language. The goal of this project is to investigate the relationship between metalinguistic awareness, multilingualism, and language learning. I designed a series of English-language tasks, including a think-aloud protocol, and survey of language learning experiences. Forty-eight adults (L1 English: 27 participants) completed the research study. This research can inform educators and learners alike on how metalinguistic awareness can improve language learning outcomes.

column5: Brooke Dawson, Amelia Harvey, Aram Soultanian, Hannah Gallagher, Lilly Nardelli
column8: Redesigned Shark Tagging
column10: Great white sharks are an apex predator of the marine ecosystem. Researchers today are trying to develop a deeper understanding of their migration patterns and predatory habits to keep beaches safer for humans. This project partnered with MA Division of Fisheries and Dr. Greg Skomal, to create a tagging mechanism to attach a CATS Cam sensor system to the dorsal fin of a great white. The safety of the user and the shark were of utmost importance in the design process. Iterations of a pole design were modelled in CAD, fabricated and tested with 3D printed plastics, and manufactured with machining equipment. This project paves the way for further data collection on great whites, leading to more awareness and predictability of shark locations.

column5: Lorrie Ataya, David Burgos, Angela Haith, Bryce Wade
column8: A Bicycle for Every Kid
column10: Muscular disabilities result in weakness and inhibit mobility. Adaptations to the standard bicycle exist, but their functions are focused on therapeutic purposes. Therefore, the project goal was to create a fun and functioning modified children's bicycle. This was validated through the assessment of functions, objectives, and constraints, as well as research and client outreach. Due to COVID, we selected two major components to focus on: the propulsion and turning mechanisms. The resulting product consisted of a working prototype that demonstrated the necessary functions. Recommendations include the material modification and safety improvement. The resulting appearance was also modified cosmetically to further reduce stigma.

column5: Isabelle Jaquith, Erica Houghton, Brittany Bolster, Christina Freni, Sofia Orrico
column8: Testing Method and Fixtures for Comparing Fatigue Loading Conditions in Bones
column10: Bone stress injuries occur when the bones cannot tolerate repeated mechanical loads. As a result, structural fatigue accumulates at the site of the injury. This kind of injury is common in athletes, accounting for 10% of orthopedic injuries. This study examined how human metatarsals may react under repeated mechanical loading using avian bones. To achieve this, a design and test fixture were developed to model the physiological conditions and loading in the metatarsals. Subject testing of avian bones were used to calculate damage accumulation after up to 30,000 cycles. This damage was used to identify the mechanical properties of bone under cyclic loading, informing preventative methods and treatment for bone stress injuries in humans.

column5: Mia Buccowich, Andrew Strauss
column8: Partial Hand Prosthetic
column10: The goal of this project was to develop a partial hand prosthetic for an amputee from Texas who was told she there were no commercially available options. Her amputation was unique in that her entire index finger was removed leaving no metacarpal to actuate a device, the method of most devices. This project explored various ways of actuating her two missing digits (index and thumb), resulting in the movement of her index finger being coupled to that of her middle finger, and the movement of the thumb controlled through pressure sensors which rest atop her metacarpal. The device also uses novel passive variable bladders in order to ensure that the harness remains stable on her hand as the index finger experiences resistance.

column5: Muntasir Shahabuddin, Eduardo Italiani
column6: Nikolaos Kazantzis, Michael Timko, Andrew Teixeira
column8: Techno-Economic Analysis to Determine the Optimal Scale of Hydrothermal Liquefaction: Effects of Learning Rates, Transportation, and Technological Improvements.
column10: Due to the depletion of fossil fuel resources and the ubiquity of biomass feedstock worldwide, renewable fuel production pathways are at the forefront of energy research. Waste-to-energy conversion processes have the potential to displace incumbent fossil fuel usage. The focus of this study is to develop a techno-economic analysis (TEA) of hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL) to determine the optimal scale of HTL plants under the effects of industry learning rates, delivery costs, and catalytic action. It was found that delivery costs dominate when feedstock is delivered due to its high volume relative to biocrude produced. These results indicate that HTL plants should predominantly be co-located with large feedstock sources.

column5: Olivia Caton, Marina Como, Jacqueline Cardin
column8: Pharmaceuticals In Wastewater
column10: Pharmaceuticals are known to cause detrimental environmental effects including the increase of antibiotic resistant bacteria and development issues in animals, but research is still limited. This study aims to observe the effect current wastewater treatment methods have on three pharmaceuticals (SMZ, azithromycin, and salicylic acid) by analyzing their concentrations after seven treatment stages. Utilizing SPE and LC-MS, we determined the effluent concentrations of SMZ and azithromyicin were 81 ppb and 209 ppb, respectively, with similar concentrations appearing in surface water. This study did not observe a reduction in pharmaceutical concentration with current wastewater treatment methods, but noted their potential.

column5: Rishi Gupta, Brandon McLaughlin
column8: Ceramic Binder Stickiness Investigation
column10: This project investigated several factors that may cause sticking within ceramic powder parts. Sticking between the die and powder has a highly detrimental effect during an automated manufacturing process. Powder residue could eventually ruin a part, thus stopping the entire process to fix the issue. Of the multitude of possible factors, several key ones were chosen for further study. These included the die temperature, the binder composition, and the number of parts created before cleaning the die. If changing these factors is significant enough, new standards for determining and preventing stickiness in the dies can be created, allowing for more complex parts, higher efficiency, and less rejection of defective parts, among other benefits.

column5: Nicole Bodinizzo, Donald Coley, Shayne Barton
column8: Revealing Surface Changes in Transparent Gallium Air Battery
column10: Gallium, a nontoxic liquid metal above 30C, demonstrates increased theoretical energy density which could perform better than commercial Li-ion batteries. For this study, a transparent cell was designed and constructed to visualize surface changes in gallium during redox cycles. As the first of its kind, the see-through cell helped us identify what happens at the failure point and why. By identifying these issues, our study aims to provide solutions that can bring gallium into commercial use.

column5: Nasim Mansuri
column8: Best Practices for Adapting Manufacturing Documentation
column10: This projects compiles a set of best practices for adapting documentation in the manufacturing industry, and applies them to a real-world case. Through literary research and interviews with employees from Shell Catalysts, Frito-Lay, Rogers Corporation, and Waters Corporation, this report illustrates how many companies across the United States structure their documentation adaptation process, the common strengths and challenges they face, and the influence of federal regulations on their decisions. These trends, combined into a checklist and example template, were then applied to the adaptation of a Matisse SSOP for use at a Frito-Lay manufacturing plant.

column5: Isaiah Aridou, Olivia Hauber
column8: Cross-Laminated Timber
column10: Mass timber is a framing category that uses large wood panels, including CLT. The goal was to explore the effectiveness of CLT through designing a renovation of an office building utilizing mass timber and comparing it to a steel alternative. ASCE 7-10, IBC-2015, AWC-NDS, AISC-15 references were used to ensure structurally sound designs. While the current cost of CLT is high due to a lack of manufacturers, the sustainability, manufacturability, and constructability benefits make CLT a competitive building material.

column5: Emma Burleson, Annemarie Eastwood, Lauren Mitchell, Molly Youngs
column8: Acid Leachate Active Treatment System at Cooledge Brook, MA
column10: This project, in conjunction with MassDEP, focused on designing and testing a pilot treatment system for an acid rock drainage (ARD) contaminated site at Cooledge Brook in Northborough, MA. Cooledge Brook was impacted by runoff from sulfidic fill rock at a nearby property, resulting in a pH of 4.5 and high levels of dissolved metals in both the groundwater and surface water. We designed, built, and operated a pilot-scale batch reactor system to assess the feasibility of a large-scale treatment system at the site. Future work such as in situ testing and automation will further improve the pilot system for scale up.

column5: Tarang Shah
column8: Redlining and Environmental Health Outcomes
column10: Redlining and other policies have reinforced segregation by race and income, in ways that shape environmental health outcomes today. Expanding on findings that previously redlined areas experience a greater urban heat island effect, this analysis of 209 cities across the country finds that areas that were redlined in the 1930s tend to have more diesel particulate matter, higher asthma rates, a larger minority population and lower incomes even today. For cities in Massachusetts, this research proceeds to identify hotspots in detail to inform policies to replace impervious areas with green space in ways that advance the livability of the city.

column5: Michael Clements, Andrew Nolan, Jackson Powell
column8: BrainEx: Visual Exploration and Discovery of Sequence Similarity in Brain Signals
column10: BrainEx is a tool for exploring and comparing sequences in time series datasets with a focus of applications on brain data. BrainEx is the successor of the tools ONEX and GENEX. Our project seeks to extend BrainEx's graphical user interface with a cluster explorer, general usability improvements, and an integrated exploration pipeline between the cluster explorer, similarity search, and feature exploration tools. These improvements provide researchers with a powerful way to explore time series data. A user study and an expert review confirmed that BrainEx provides time series exploration in ways existing tools do not.

column5: Bryce Corbitt, Pooja Patel
column8: Development and Assessment of a Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction Mobile Application
column10: The goal of this Major Qualifying Project (MQP) is to continue development of a mobile platform to assist college students in the practice of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR). This project is a continuation of two previous Major Qualifying Projects (MQP) that conducted research and proposed designs for the app, and an Interactive Qualifying Project (IQP) that started development of the "doyoumindful" prototype application. The platform was improved upon by building a video player to stream video content, and creating an in-house events system to record app usage information. A user study of 30 participants was conducted to assess the effectiveness of the new video player, which also served to test the reliability of the back-end.

column5: Imogen Cleaver-Stigum, Erik Reimert Burro
column8: Clustering Hippocampal Neuron Action Potentials Using Autoencoders and Autoencoder-Kalman Filtering for Noise Reduction
column10: In this project, we applied the deep learning methods of autoencoder-Kalman filtering as well as the autoencoder preprocessing from Ciecierski (2020) to improve clustering on action potentials by filtering noise. We used multiple types of clustering, including k-means clustering, mean-shift clustering, and agglomerative hierarchical clustering. We evaluated the performance of each clustering algorithm after using each filtering method, as well as no filtering, to analyze which of the filtering methods has the best effect on clustering action potentials.

column5: Shaolin Xie
column8: Database-Integrated Analytics
column10: The coordination between data analytics and database systems becomes exceedingly important in order to efficiently analyze data that is stored inside the database. This project compared two approaches that integrate machine learning with database systems: client-server connection and in-database processing. Two machine learning models - Support Vector Machine and Random Forest - were implemented using each of the approaches and then tested on datasets of different scales. After comparing the run-time efficiency and the testing accuracy of the two approaches, I generated the conclusion regarding which approach has better performance.

column5: Alan Curiel, Kyle Smith
column8: GearTrain: Converting WinForms Gear Design Software to WPF
column10: The goal of this project is to convert gear design software made in a previous MQP from the outdated Windows Forms graphics framework to the newer WPF framework, and improve it. Through many user studies, we were able to determine how users responded to the software to see what changes should be made. Users recommended that a 3D representation of the gear train design be added, so that was included in the system. After many iterative refinement steps through the User Interface and program flow, our users generally agree that our new program, titled GearTrain, is a significant improvement over the previous system. GearTrain teaches Mechanical Engineering students about gear concepts and simplifies the design of gear trains.

column5: Samatha Grillo, Kalani Picho, Kenneth Rhodes, Alec Kneedler
column6: Marko Popovic, George Heineman, Gregory Fischer
column7: Computer Science,Electrical & Computer Engineering,Mechanical Engineering,Robotics Engineering
column8: Bio-Inspired Interactive Dino
column10: The goal of this MQP was to design, fabricate, and implement an interactive robot model of the head and neck of a Deinonychus that creates the impression of a living dinosaur. The neck contains 6 actuated degrees of freedom and is composed of custom-made vertebrae. The vertebral column is modelled and controlled as a continuum arm. The project makes use of Popovic Lab's Hydro Muscles, which are elastic linear actuators that replicate muscular motion. These Hydro Muscles are powered by a custom hydraulic system and control the dinosaur neck by pulling on wire 'tendons' that are attached to key points on the neck. The team focused on elements that mimicked anatomical structures in order to develop a system to mimic lifelike behavior.

column5: Ryan Carnemolla, Anirban Mukherjee, Amrit Parmanand, Emily Staknis
column8: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping with Atlas
column10: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) is a powerful method for autonomously exploring new environments that had never been applied to humanoid robots. This project developed SLAM on the Atlas humanoid robot, allowing it to interact with and explore novel environments. The Atlas robot was programmed to create 3 dimensional maps of environments and localize itself within them. Due to constraints in time and safety the project was conducted mostly in simulation. Both stereo cameras and LiDar were used in experiments to identify the robot's surroundings and avoid obstacles. These sensors paired with the robot's locomotion allowed the Atlas robot to search and navigate unknown areas.

column5: Ryan Doyle, Irakli Grigolia, Kyria Nelson
column8: Creating an App for Audio Journal's Print Disabled Listeners
column10: As the world becomes more internet-oriented, it presents several unique challenges for people with blindness and visual impairments to access local news. Audio Journal is a radio reading service in Worcester, MA that broadcasts local news to blind and visually impaired people in Central Massachusetts. They wanted to improve access to their content by allowing their users to listen on demand without having to access their website. To achieve this goal, our project group created an iPhone app that was determined to be the best option towards improving accessibility for Audio Journal's current and future listeners. The app was developed and tested in phases over the course of 21 weeks, and is available on the App Store for download.

column5: Juliette Spitaels, Victoria Mirecki
column8: "My Brain Does Not Function That Way'': Comparing Quilters' Perceptions and Motivations Towards Computing and Quilting
column10: While quilting has been used as a metaphor to help people understand Computer Science, the majority of these lessons have been done in the context of K-16 education. In our research we explore how this metaphor extends to already skilled craftspeople outside of formal learning environments. To investigate this, we first wanted to understand the similarities and differences between the ways that quilters think about quilting and the ways that they think about CS and computing more broadly. We held a focus group with seven quilters and asked them to compare their perceptions and experiences related to both fields. Through grounded theory analysis, we examined the conversation to understand the methods to best engage quilters in CS education.

column5: Dante Muzila, Revant Mahajan, Ankur Gupta, Andrew Euredjian
column6: Michael Gennert, Mahdi Agheli, Randy Paffenroth
column8: Multi-Modal Locomotion Robot
column10: The goal of this project is to implement multi-modalism on the Solo8. In the current field of legged robotics, quadrupedal and bipedal robots are distinctly optimized for specific environments and tasks. This limits their adaptability across unstructured environments. In nature, we commonly see animals like primates, dogs, and bears overcome the inefficiencies of a single locomotion type by switching between quadrupedalism and bipedalism. However, very few robotic platforms can do this. A multi-modal robotic platform would provide additional adaptability in unstructured environments, broadening its potential applications. In this project, we extended an existing quadrupedal platform with the capability to transition into a bipedal stance.

column5: James Scherick
column8: GaPA: A Program to Assist Novices with 3D Printing
column10: The 3D printing process can be daunting for novices, requiring knowledge of a multitude of settings to determine a part's optimal printing configuration. Current existing software tools overwhelm users with customizable settings. The goal of this project is to create a software application (GaPA) that will guide novices through the process of printing a part using an intuitive interface. It generates high quality G-Code for a printer, using automatically-selected settings based on user preferences. GaPA can serve as an introduction to slicing programs before users move to more complex software. GaPA has been tested with groups of WPI undergraduate students in Design and Manufacturing.

column5: Brian Wilkinson, Scott Rementer, Perla Wehbe
column8: Palm Print
column10: Additive manufacturing (AM) has revolutionized the manufacturing world. It allows for the manufacturing of complex parts that would not normally be possible using traditional manufacturing methods. Since AM is a very cost effective and efficient way of manufacturing, it has become one of the most popular types of rapid prototyping. Rapid prototyping is very important during technical education because it allows students to work hands-on with their designs and learn more about designing for manufacturing. 3D printers can be very costly to purchase and are very difficult to move, after its initial set up. In this project, we look into a cost effective and compact 3D printer that can easily fit inside a student's backpack.

column5: Sarah Strazdus, Lauren Handel
column6: Robert Krueger, Mustapha Fofana, Matthew Amissah
column8: Engineering Solutions for Ghana E-Waste Problems
column10: The Engineering Solutions for Ghana E-Waste Problems MQP provides a grinder to pulverize electronic waste in Agbogbloshie, a scrap yard in Ghana. Ghanaian expertise guided the project's focus on manufacturing and sustainable maintenance. SOLIDWORKS and ANSYS simulation tools were used to visualize and test the design. A steel prototype was assembled using the tools in Washburn Shops at WPI. Future revisions of the E-waste Recycling Grinder could scale a manufacturing plan and determine a grinder integration plan for Agbogbloshie.

column5: Yingbing Lu, Robert Batista,Sonia Litovchick, Lannan Jiang
column8: An Intuitive User Interface for Teleoperated Robotic Neuro-Intervention
column10: Interventional procedures navigate small instruments such as guidewires and catheters through the blood vessels under X-ray imaging guidance to treat diseases including ischemic heart disease and stroke. Interventional procedures can be performed remotely via robotic catheterization. The interventional devices are manipulated by a robot controlled remotely by the interventionalists. The team designed and prototyped a system that allows the interventionalists to perform the traditional over-the-wire technique and received haptic feedback during robotic catheterization. This intuitive user interface minimizes the learning curve in the clinical adoption of robotic catheterization and could enhance global healthcare service and equity.

column5: Davina Dawson
column8: Rigs of Color Pt. 1
column10: The Rigs of Color project focuses on developing diverse three-dimensional character models. These models will be available for open use on the internet, with a focus on being a resource for students learning animation. This project centered around developing seven characters of various ethnic backgrounds. Characters were taken from base concept art to fully modeled, clothed, and colored models.

column5: Matthew Finley
column8: On A Fair Multiflow Problem
column10: The goal of my project is to find a good way of solving a new variant of the multi-flow problem, where the ratio of different flows must be preserved in maximization. While I was unable to find an exact example of this problem, I was able to find a related problem on maximizing the minimal flow, from a recent paper.

column5: Anh Quang Huynh, Daniel Askman
column8: Temperature Control Mattress
column10: The goal of our project is to develop a specific mattress technology that could increase users' sleep quality. Sleep deprivation has had a negative impact on public health and society's level of productivity: by correcting the mattress temperature based on the human temperature-circadian rhythm, we can enhancing one's sleep quality tremendously throughout the night. To approach this challenge, we will first research how temperature, bed material deformation, and noise level affect sleep. Then, following the established criteria, we will start to brainstorm possible solutions. With the support of ANSYS software, we will evaluate the options and finalize the design and the plan to prototype the products with a proper testing process.

column5: Eric Stultz, Dexter Czuba, Steven Gordon, Rajkumar Dandekar
column8: PARV: A 3D Printed Autonomous Robotic Vehicle Platform
column10: For our project, we are designing, manufacturing, and testing a primarily 3D printable remote controlled delivery car. A few of the unique systems this car incorporates are a fully functional transfer case for four wheel driving, and adaptable platform for sensor and payload integration. This car is a platform model that is capable of having many new systems and components added to it. For example, the car currently incorporates an autonomous driving module, a commercially available robotic arm, and a powered detachable trailer for various payloads. This car is built with modularity in mind so that it can be easily adjusted and improved based on the obstacles or tasks it encounters.

column5: Aaron McCutcheon, Nancy Nguyen, Eric Scholz, Rebecca Serven, Spencer Tess
column8: Triboelectric Energy Generation for the Army
column10: Our project team, partnering with the US Army Combat Capabilities Development Command Soldier Center, aims to explore the use of triboelectric nanogenerators (TENGs) for use in portable energy production and storage for the Army. By utilizing two different materials, each connected to separate electrodes, a voltage can be generated from electrostatic induction and the triboelectric effect. When these materials engage in cycles of contact and separation, mechanical energy is collected and converted to electrical power, which can be stored or used in self-powered electronics. In this project, the performance of eight different Army textiles are evaluated as triboelectric materials for implementation in wind and impact based applications.

column5: Cam Tu Le
column6: Yuxiang Liu, Douglas Petkie, James Eakin
column8: Integrated Photonic Device Fabrication, Assembly, and Characterization: WPI/QCC LEAP Facility Testing and Customization
column10: The objective of the MQP is to test some of LEAP's equipment and develop its protocols. However, due to the scope of the project, we were only able to examine the spin coater, the Profilometer, and the TeraHertz spectroscopy. Among many pieces of equipment at the WPI/QCC LEAP, we choose the spin coater and Profilometer for testing because they are essential parts and are frequently used in integrated photonic device fabrication. Furthermore, in this MQP work, we will use the Toptica TeraFlash, a time-domain spectrometer, to extract the Quartz glass slide's refractive index and absorption coefficients and then compare it with available literature.

column5: Julia Cuendet
column8: Study of Boilover in Wave Tank
column10: The goal of this project is to understand how fuel floating on water affects burning and to examine how the addition of waves changes this interaction. As In-Situ burning becomes a more viable way to clean up oil spills, it is increasingly important to study the combustion of liquid fuels floating on water. This often leads to explosive burning called boilover. Boilover occurs when the heat from the fuel is transferred to the water underneath, which can cause the water to boil and cause splashing. In this study, thin layers of kerosene poured into a circular, floating test pan were burned in a rectangular water-filled tank. The tank is equipped with a wave generator. Several initial fuel layer thicknesses and wave profiles were tested.

column5: Nathaniel Shimkus, Nicholas Giaquinto, Parrish Garver
column8: Optimizing Climbing Cam Design
column10: The goal of this project is to create a better mechanical design for microcams to increase their holding power and safety. Microcams are small camming devices that are used in the sport of rock climbing and act as a form of protection to prevent a rock climber from taking dangerous falls. By researching the mechanisms that allow climbing cams to operate and iterating on those mechanisms, different ideas on how to increase the holding power can be explored. These designs can then be manufactured into reality. The use of tensile tests allow for the holding power of the new cam designs to be tested and compared to other climbing cams currently on the market.

column5: Elliana Budri, Derek Comeau, Nicole Kring, Jon Sorenson
column8: Train of Four Device
column10: The goal of our project is to expand on a previous MQP teams work. We have redeveloped the model and design plan for an anesthetic-use monitoring device that determines the depth of muscle paralyzing drugs (neuromuscular blocking agents) in patients. This device uses a unique technology called Mechanomyography, which is considered the gold standard method for identifying the depth of muscular block in surgical procedures. Our report concentrated on prototyping, researching the market, and understanding the science behind the risks of improper administration of neuromuscular blocking agents.

column5: Julia DeLo, Eric Motler, Jacqueline Kral, Mary Rosati
column8: Low-Profile Home Speaker Design: A Discreet Speaker that Uses Pivoting Actuators and Moving Magnet Transducers
column10: The goal of this Major Qualifying Project (MQP) was to determine the qualities of an effective speaker box enclosure that utilized a pivoting actuator, speaker cones, and passive radiators to generate sound. The first step in this process was to evaluate existing hardware to determine what improvements could be made. Then, the team focused on developing the lever actuator into a standalone prototype that could produce vibrations in a speaker box enclosure. Finite element analysis, including the use of multiple ANSYS softwares, was applied to determine the effectiveness of the different hardwares and technologies applied to each prototype throughout the MQP process. Physical tests were also performed to validate the simulations.

column5: Sabrina Liu, Philip Abell, Samuel Johnson, Zhongchuan Xu
column8: SCREAM 3.0: Super-elastic Continuum Robot for Endoscopic Articulation and Manipulation
column10: Laryngeal tumors are common, yet challenging to treat endoscopically due to the lack of articulation in existing surgical instruments. Teaming up with a doctor at Brigham and Women's Hospital, we created an integrated, miniaturized, steerable laser sheath to make formerly untreatable tumors accessible and operable. We present the design and construction of a continuum robotic manipulator consisting of a notched tube capable of providing pan and tilt degrees of freedom. The system encompasses a steerable wrist, control handle, and actuation module that integrates with the endoscopic handle currently being used by physicians.

column5: Yvonne Niebuhr
column8: Improving Oral Contraceptives
column10: The goal of this project was to encourage research into oral contraceptives (OCs) and their side effects, as well as to conduct original research into this topic. OCs, commonly known as birth control pills, are known to have a wide range of side effects that are difficult to predict and address. These side effects are underresearched, causing a lack of knowledge for both patients and their healthcare providers. In this project, I investigated the factors behind this lack of research, developed a blueprint for future research by use of a survey that asked participants about their experiences with OCs, designed a tool that patients can use to troubleshoot side effects they experience with OCs, and encouraged further research into this topic.

column5: Katharine Edel, Sarah Hoac, Rhianna Shanabrook
column8: Developing a Knee Prosthesis
column10: Millions of people need above-the-knee prostheses, yet their designs are not perfected. The goal of this project was to create a knee prosthesis that aids users in traversing stairs with greater ease than current knee prostheses. Our prosthesis utilized a four-bar mechanism to mimic the motion and forces a healthy knee sustains; the prosthesis resulted in an improvement in knee flexion angles while walking and stair traversing compared to current models. Overall, our prosthesis successfully met the necessary design goals.

column5: Owen Carlstrom, Andrea Fialli, Oliver Thomas
column8: Design of an Autonomous Canine Entertainment Device
column10: The goal of this project was to develop an autonomous canine entertainment device for dogs while owners are away. The team utilized the design process to develop a device that automatically launched dog treats. The device contained four mechanisms to successfully contain, individually dispense, retract and launch the treats one at a time. A rotating arm placed within the treat container provided continuous motion of treats at the outlet. The treats were individually dispensed from the outlet with a linear motion linkage system. Lastly, a rotating cam arm retracted and launched the treat with elastic potential. Each mechanism was programmed to run simultaneously. Recommendations for future improvement were provided.

column5: Bailey Berg, Jordan DeDonato, Michael Keable, Thien Q. Nguyen, Griffin St. Onge
column6: Christopher A. Brown, Walter T. Towner
column8: Creation of a Sport Backstop Using Axiomatic Design
column10: The objective of this project was to design and physically develop an affordable, meaning under $500 retail price, device that can accurately provide feedback on speed and position of a pitch. Current products like this are usually either expensive, inaccurate or both. Additionally, they often lack feedback on position of the pitch over the Homeplate. Due to these limitations, customers are often dissatisfied with the smart backstop product they have purchased. Axiomatic design theory and concept-knowledge theory were used in the design of a new smart backstop product. Our team has come to a solution that can provide more accurate results for speed and position of a pitch and provide feedback in a clear and user-friendly manner.

column5: Rachel Arnold, Trevor Karrett, Chloe Melville
column8: Ischemic Stroke Detection
column10: Each year 795,000 Americans suffer from a stroke, 87% of them being ischemic where a blood clot travels from the heart to the brain causing irreparable damage. The potentially fatal consequences of these strokes could be avoided with early detection and removal of the clot. We developed phantom models of the neck and carotid artery for testing. Artificial blood and clots were pumped through the model, and an ultrasound probe connected to a computer running a computer vision algorithm was used to detect them. Our proof of concept shows that a wearable device could be created to preemptively detect ischemic strokes for at risk patients.

column5: Samantha Morton, Leah White, Alyssa Webb, Julia Premo, Alexa Eves
column8: Gompei's Lab-Grown Leather
column10: The goal of this project is to reduce waste in the current leather making process through the establishment of a device capable of cell seeding on a plant scaffold while additionally allowing for the perfusion of media. The current leather making process poses as a detriment to society given the vast amount of waste and excess harmful chemicals that are produced from the process. Researchers aim to understand the dynamics of growing bovine dermis and its mechanical properties well enough to produce a device capable of growing a sheet of lab-grown leather. The results of our device will be compared to the current leather making process.

column5: Adam Saar, Dennis Leary, Camden Kulczyk
column8: FPE Wave Tank
column10: The goal of this project is to design and build a modular wave tank to be used by the fire protection engineering department for medium scale, crude oil burns. Wave tanks have always been bulky and difficult to move, however with the tank being modular in design, it will allow the FPE department to disassemble and store away the tank in a more compact shape allowing for other experiments to be performed in the lab when the tank is not in use.

column5: Nicholas Merianos, Samuel Winslow, Andrew Poutry, Margaret Drogalis
column8: A Modular Cryogenic Storage Solution
column10: The goal of this project is to design a modular system designed for keeping objects inside it's storage volume at extremely low temperatures for extended periods of time. The Covid-19 pandemic has started an increased need for extreme cold storage with many vaccines needing to be stored at subzero temperatures prior to injection to remain viable. This paired with testing devices designed for extreme conditions displays a unique need for a new vessel designed for transport or testing of components needing extremely low temperatures. We will design a modular vessel that will be able to satisfy these needs.

column5: Jordan Stoessel
column8: Recreating the First Haptic Cinema Experience with Smartphones
column10: The goal of this project was to recreate the first haptic cinema experience through modern technology. We designed and implemented a mobile application that recreates the experience of Percepto, a haptic (tactile) cinema technology originally developed for Columbia's 1959 feature film "The Tingler". Utilizing Google's UI software development kit, Flutter, together with Firebase, and TypeScript, a client-server architecture was created that allows synchronized control of vibrations across multiple Android of iOS devices. Research with this project was used to understand the OS limitations of these mobile devices and in creating appropriate solutions.

column5: Ellen Abayo, Nicole Escobar, James Kahn, Dalibor Kresovic, Nicholas Sackos, Jake Sullivan
column6: David J Olinger, Jagannath Jayachandran, Zhangxian Yuan
column8: Design and Testing of a Fixed Wing Micro-Aerial Vehicle
column10: Micro-Aerial Vehicles (MAVs) are a unique type of aircraft with small size, low weight, and high versatility. The goal of this project was to design, build, and test an MAV that carried a payload of 55 grams in order to compete in the 2021 WPI MAV Competition. The competition scoring equation rewards small MAV size, long flight times, and the ability to make on-board inertial measurements. The design process involved four subgroups focused on aerodynamics, propulsion, stability, and structures. The final aircraft was constructed using foam, with a maximum length of 55cm and a mass of 400 grams excluding the 55 gram payload. This MAV was able to fly for the maximum allowed time of four minutes while taking nine inertial measurements.

column5: Yen-Chen Chen
column8: Flow Coupling Between Active and Passive Fluids Across Interfaces of Compressed Active Droplets
column10: Active fluid is differed from passive fluid by its ability of consuming internal fuels to generate mechanical work. Here we explored the self-organization of the active fluid confined in a water-in-oil droplet. We found that the fluid developed intra-droplet circulatory flows when the droplet was compressed into a cylinder-like shape. When the droplet was compressed further into pancake-like shape, the circulatory flow was suppressed. Inspired by this result, we invented a device that controlled the compression magnitude, enabling us to turn on and off the circulatory flow in real time. This work paves the path to developing an active fluid-powered machine whose power is manually tuned like a gas pedal of a car.

column5: Jack Chase, Tim Giddings, Ryan Johnson, Sabrina Cacapit, Sullivan Boyd, Kevin Boenisch, Nick Alescio, Jack Ruddat, Ben Steeves, Kyle France, Nathaniel Bajakian, Tobias Schaeffer, Julia Duffield, Trevor Ninesling, Clayton Besch, Anavat Siamwala, Noah Parker
column7: Computer Science,Electrical & Computer Engineering,Mechanical Engineering,Robotics Engineering
column8: Design and Optimization of an Electric FSAE Vehicle
column10: This project represents the efforts of 17 students across four majors to design WPI's first Formula SAE Electric race car. Formula SAE Electric is an engineering design competition where collegiate teams from around the world build electric race cars to compete in events on and off the track. The most challenging aspect of this competition is the endurance event, where many cars experience failure. To complete this event, we considered reliability and serviceability from the systems level all the way down to individual component design. This is the first of two years of development, so our prototypes will be passed on to next year's team to be finalized and face extensive testing before going to competition.

column5: Johnny Chea, Connor Bourgeois
column8: 3D Printing of Liquid Silicone Rubber
column10: We were then tasked to research the current field of silicone printing along with developing a 3d printer extruder for liquid silicone rubber. Despite how far additive manufacturing has developed as of today, there are countless opportunities to advance the field such as standardized printing of silicone rubber. Silicone is a polymer frequently throughout aerospace, textile, automotive and healthcare industries due to its bio-compatibility, distinct qualities of a high elasticity, and the ability to withstand stress and heat. We will determine the necessary processes and equipment to form silicon and construct our own heated silicone injection printer system.

column5: Brian Preiss, Timothy Welch, Aidan Sevinsky, Cooper Milsark
column8: Redesigning Alpine Helmets
column10: Alpine skiing can be a very dangerous sport due to the risk of traumatic brain injury as a result of crashing. This can lead to severe reduction in neurological function, with repeat injuries linked to Alzheimers and Parkinsons disease, as well as chronic traumatic encephalopathy. Current alpine helmets are made of two layers: a rigid outer shell and a compressible foam layer of either EPP or EPS. However, the foam layer offers limited protection during compression, and none after it has compressed by roughly a half an inch. Our objective is to design a new energy absorption system for these helmets to reduce the risk of concussions and withstand multiple impacts.

column5: Zackary Fitzgibbon, Kate Fabrizio, Rakesh Veetekat
column8: Feature Recognition from Aerial Imaging
column10: The goal of this project is to extract key information from video data provided by a camera-mounted parachute and use it to help the parachute navigate in the air. The video provided by the parachute is utilized as input to a variety of algorithms that should instruct the parachute how to maneuver itself in the air to reach its destination. The reason why this method of navigation is being explored is because the traditional way of utilizing GPS to help the parachute plot a route to its destination can be unreliable, especially during instances of harsh weather. We researched and tested many algorithms that use the video data obtained from the parachute to develop a procedure that would rely on video more than GPS to steer the parachute.

column5: Jax Sprague, Douglas Koethe, Jasmin Sanchez, Brendan Cicione, Joseph Kirsh, Mathew Siu, Sophia Brennan, Nathan Fankhanel
column6: Ahmet Can Sabuncu, Rajib Mallick, Stephan Sturm, Jennifer Rudolph
column8: Urban Farming Interdisciplinary Major Qualifying Project
column10: Flats Mentor Farm (FMF) currently irrigates 7 acres of farmland by pumping well water to holding tanks, from which farmers must fill buckets that they carry a great distance to their plots to water their crops manually. The project team developed and proposed alternative irrigation methods to replace the existing system, considering various irrigators, filtration systems, and pump designs, and eventually deciding on a MegaNet sprinkler system driven by an unused gasoline-powered pump at FMF, with layflat line and PVC connections. To simulate the system, the project team built a small-scale prototype simulating irrigation. The irrigation system prototype demonstrated proper MegaNet sprinkler function at low pressure.

column5: Yu Him Au, Olivia Lattanzi, Dan Seeley, Claire Victor
column8: A Comprehensive Mechanical Engineering Perspective on the Implementation of an Organic Rankine Cycle for Data Center Waste Heat Recovery
column10: Modern digitalization has led to massive growth in data center (DC) electricity consumptionhalf of which is dedicated to IT equipment cooling. This project investigated the viability of an organic Rankine cycle (ORC) for DC waste heat recovery in terms of mechanical practicality, sustainability, and economic feasibility. A liquid cooling system for capturing CPU waste heat with microchannel heat sinks was designed with COMSOL simulation software. An integrated thermodynamic, fluid, and heat exchanger analysis was developed in MATLAB to fully characterize the ORC heat recovery system. The payback period of the optimized design was under 5 years, thereby enabling the DC to reduce energy demands, as well as generate revenue from its cooling.

column5: Max Frohlich, Alana Guilbault, Kevin Mercier, Evan Ryan
column8: Automotive Waste Heat Recovery: A Semi-Truck Exhaust Application
column10: The goal of this project was to determine the feasibility of using thermoelectric generation as a method of collecting waste heat from a standard semi-truck exhaust system. Prior research regarding the efficacy of thermoelectric generators to reclaim wasted energy in mechanical processes inspired this project. An assembly for housing thermoelectric generators on the exhaust stack of a semi-truck was designed and optimized based on its structural integrity, potential power generation, and subsequent cost savings. The results obtained may direct future engineering research as to whether or not thermoelectric power generation is a worthwhile technology to pursue.

column5: Xavier McLean
column8: Crash Course in Screenwriting and Film Production
column10: The goal of this project was to learn the basics of screenwriting and film production. This was accomplished by writing an original short film script and producing a subsequent film adaptation. This paper documents the writing, development, and production of the short film Timer, a student film created in the Spring of the 2020-2021 school year.
